awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dynamics of surface rupturing thrust earthquakes
awd_abstract_narration:
Surface rupturing thrust earthquakes are particularly troublesome: any person or structure unfortunate enough to be in the vicinity of the upthrust side of the fault will experience stronger than usual ground motion. Making matters worse, if the fault happens to be submarine then it may also create a tsunami.  Understanding the dynamics of these events is critical to mitigate seismic and tsunami risk. Current observational approaches, however, are hindered by several major limitations:  they lack sensitivity to the dynamically important shallowest portion of the fault and they may ignore important geometrical effects including that of the free surface or material property contrasts. This project will advance our fundamental understanding of surface rupturing thrust earthquakes, tsunamigenesis, earthquake source physics, and ground motion more generally. It involves developing innovative observational methodologies and generating improved mechanical descriptions of earthquake processes. The proposed research bridges mechanical and observational perspectives on earthquake processes to validate physical models and make predictions of future damaging earthquakes. The exposure to tsunami and shaking hazard for large, surface rupturing thrust inevitably increases with global population growth. The proposed research will provide key information on earthquake processes that are relevant to populated areas including Japan (Nankai), India (Main Himalayan Thrust), and the United States (Cascadia) that are expecting shallow megathrust earthquakes. The project includes the supervising of two graduate students, one or more undergraduate students, the course development of a sophomore-level class and the improvement of a graduate level class. It also involves the promotion of earthquake sciences at the Harvard Museum of Natural History through the development of an interactive exhibit. 

Physics-based approaches, such as dynamic simulations, are restricting in that they do not yet systematically provide adequate metrics to be validated against data.  This project addresses these limitations in the context of surface rupturing thrust earthquakes, including subduction zone megathrust earthquakes. The project will address all three issues by i) improving the observational methodologies toward analysis of full waveforms through time and frequency domains, and ii) testing model hypothesis and observational methodologies through dynamic simulations and seismic observations from global thrust earthquakes. The work will also include the creation of a global database of earthquake moment-rate functions, static and dynamic source parameters, and energy partitioning estimates. Finally, through validation of the physical models against observations from past megathrust earthquakes, the project will build scenario sources for well-imaged subduction zones that are expecting large surface ruptures. The scenarios will have societal impact for the earthquake and tsunami mitigation effort in the Pacific Northwest of the United States and globally around the Pacific coastlines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zones host the largest earthquakes in the world, creating extensive structural damage due to shaking and coastal destruction due to their tsunami. This project focused on understanding the range of earthquake dynamics and how it can be constrained by seismic observations for a vast range of sizes and depths of earthquakes. We explored how teleseismic back projection images can have the physical interpretation of earthquake kinematics as related to local slip rate functions (Yin and Denolle, 2019). A global analysis of earthquake source time functions, which are the time history of the source kinematics, gave us an exciting view of earthquakes as self-organized physical systems (Danre et al., 2019) that can be predicted by current physical models and how shallow earthquakes, in particular strike-slip earthquakes, tended to be more complex (Li, Yin, Denolle, 2020). Such global analysis shed light on how earthquakes in subduction zones tended to be simpler and less heterogeneous (Danre et al., 2019; Li et al., 2020).

 

Our work demonstrated a ubiquitous property of shallow thrust earthquakes: the shallow portion of the rupture instead emits low-frequency signals. In contrast, the deeper part of the fault tended to emit higher frequency. While the previous literature has evoked on-fault frictional heterogeneity or off-fault bulk heterogeneity as the mechanisms for such observations, we demonstrated using numerical analysis that the sole presence of the Earth’s free surface and how seismic waves radiated from the source interact with it can explain the frequency-dependence in the seismic radiation. We then demonstrated that the shallow portion of the fault instead hosts large and slow slips, while the deeper part tends to host short and fast slip pulses (Yin and Denolle, 2020). Bulk heterogeneity and, more particularly, low-velocity layers above the subducting slab could enhance this feature. Our work also highlighted that shear wave structure was the main driver for the speed of rupture propagation, yet it is poorly known in subduction zones relative to P wave velocity models. Preliminary work on coupling dynamic rupture models to wave propagation simulation demonstrated challenges in recovering broadband synthetic seismograms with well-separated phases to further analyze observations.

 

The project also aimed to improve the quality of earthquake signals from offshore, which are recorded on coastal stations but polluted by microseismic noise. Earthquakes of magnitude M6-7 have a duration similar to microseisms and thus are typically ignored in seismic studies and poorly understood. We tackled this issue by developing a machine-learning model that separates seismic noise from earthquake signals. WaveDecompNet (Yin et al., 2021) was designed to be computationally efficient by directly decomposing the wavefields from time series data instead of requiring a time-frequency representation. The model predicts seismic noise and earthquake signals separately. In the methodological paper, we demonstrated that 1) earthquake signals were enhanced in quality with better hope for seismic detection, and 2) noise signals were less disturbed with enhanced coherence of ambient seismic noise cross-correlations. In the next step, we used WaveDecompNet as a kernel to a larger model (Denote, Shi, et al., 2023) that separates noise from teleseismic noise. From these cleaned waveforms, we extracted earthquake source parameters of deeper earthquakes, from which denoising would be an incremental improvement. While we confirmed previous work reporting deep earthquake source parameters, we doubled the number of earthquakes and analyzed the spectral properties of magnitude five earthquakes. The stress drop and radiated energy of earthquakes are strong the larger the earthquakes, more so than crustal earthquakes. Despite this, we still find low radiation efficiency and no clear break of scaling over the magnitude range 5-8. We concluded that dual mechanisms by which a trigger (dehydration embrittlement or phase transformation) must lead to a dissipative and confined rupture that spends more energy in frictional and fracturing work.

 

Furthermore, we explore the evolution of near-fault seismic properties during and after the 2004 Parkfield Earthquakes in California. We found that near-fault materials experience co-seismic damage and slow (~ 8 year) healing post the 2004 Parkfield earthquake (Okubo et al, 2024), confirming previous studies. We also found a statistically significant long term increase in seismic velocities that can be explained by the compression of the off-fault cracks during inter-seismic loading (Okubo et al, 2004).

 

This project supported two postdoctoral fellows, two graduate students, and a junior faculty.

 


Last Modified: 12/25/2023
Modified by: Marine A Denolle
